Know this is an old video, but just some thoughts.

While the solubility is listed at 20g/100ml, it may depend on how the solution is prepared. I’ve worked with compounds that we could make a stable solution at something like 20 mg/ml, however we had to prepare the solution at ~3x the target concentration and then filter it. If we tried to prepare at the target concentration we were unable to prepare a solution within a reasonable time (1-2 hours).

i too think, that the ammonium chloride might have reacted with ammonium carbonate .the carbonate is a very potent base as we know much stronger than ammonia so a salt/base displacement is not unthinkable. with that you would get sodium chloride and ammonia. and in dilute ammonia it is extremely well soluble so your best bet was probably adding a ridiculous excess of ammonium chloride to react off the carbonate as you did and bring the solution to a gentle simmer to get the ammonia out. it should free up a lot of the ammonium metavanadate. (to calculate the excess of ammonium chloride you probably could estimate how much Na2CO3 you added and assume a 1:1 stecheometry. i doubt bicarbonate is strong enough to deprotonate ammonium salts but carbonate? easy peasy. i would even assume the acid base/salt base reaction to occur faster than the ion displacement. sounds crazy but acid base reactions can get crazy fast.  )

I used to be a trainee (3yr) and worker (1yr) in a company that made and sold various salts, oxides and complexes of vanadium in various oxidation states. While being a trainee i helped producing AMV on the ton scale.
We use almost the same route to precipitating the AMV, except instead of NH4Cl we used (NH4)2SO4-solution to introduce the ammonium ions, and the temperature when adding the AMSUL was around 30°C if i remember correctly. We also only used a small excess of AMSUL but still got the AMV to precipitate almost quantitatively - but you already figured out that an excess of NH4 can mess with your yield.
I'm not really sure if chloride vs. sulfate makes a huge difference, but maybe if you have to make more of the AMV, you might give it a try if you like.

Sodium metavanadate is pale yellow, as all oxygen-coordinated vanadium (V) compounds, so that brown-green precipitate clearly wasn't sodium metavanadate. You MUST have had vanadium present in lower oxydation states.

And indeed, commercial vanadium pentoxide often contains large amounts of vanadium III and IV oxides. Even "pure" vanadium pentoxide can be non-stoichiometric with large amounts of oxygen vacancies compensated by vanadium (IV) ions in the lattice.

That would explain why your reaction mixture turned brown, then green : vanadium IV ions are often blue, and vanadium III are usually green. The mixture of all that would indeed give you a murky brown, that would turn to an emerald green as vanadium (IV) dismutates into vanadium (V) and (III).

That is also likely why it took more water to get the whole thing to dissolve. Or maybe it just took some time for oxygen from the air to oxidize the whole thing to vanadium (V)

As for the extra ammonium chloride, perhaps some of it went into forming coordination complexes with vanadium III in solution rather than doing that exchange reaction with the sodium metavanadate. (I'd expect such complexes to be brightly colored though, so I'm really not sure on that one).

Just did some thermo modelling on this system (OLI), looks like the Ammonium Metavanadate just requires a high degree of supersaturation to initial precipitation. Adding the additional ammonium chloride appears to have solved this problem. The extra carbonate only has a slight effect on the solubility of Ammonium Metavanadate; gradually increasing its solubility on further addition.

i would say that you needed the additional ammonium chloride because you had to add additional sodium carbonate resulting in an excess. sodium carbonate is basic while the ammonium chloride is acidic so they will have reacted in situ, reducing the amount present to displace the product

I was gonna suggest that the need to add more ammonium chloride was potentially due to the excess sodium carbonate that you added, but I guess you pointed that out. Could be that by raising the pH slightly you increased the solubility of the sodium metavanadate in solution, and  the excess of ammonium chloride wasn't enough to neutralise/acidify the solution, however when you added the second portion, this was enough to lower the pH enough to the point of precipitation.

hey Nile... I think "Common Ion Effect" is the reason why much of the NH4VO3 precipitated when you added the Ammonium chloride. The concentration of the Ammonium ions increase. Thus decreasing the solubility of your product.

Theory 1: The extra sodium carbonate that you added could have reacted with the ammonium ions to produce ammonia and carbon dioxide (leaving behind sodium chloride) or sodium bicarbonate.
Theory 2: The extra ammonium ions influenced the solubility of ammonium metavanadate and caused it to crush out of solution. It could be like adding potassium chloride to a saturated silver chloride solution. Silver Chloride will crush out because it is less soluble.

I think the problem with the precipitation is that since you have an excess of carbonate, the basicity help to generate ammonia from ammonium chloride, plus with high temperature, ammonium chloride decompose to form ammonia. In the end you have less ammonium ion to react with vanadate anion...
Could it be possible that the reaction between V2O5 and Na2CO3 is simply slow and that the extra water wasn't really necessary?

When sodium carbonate is dissolved in water it's forming a base. Ammonium ions react with a base and form ammonia. May be the extra sodium carbonate made it alkaline. When it's cold the reaction is slower and the Ammonium metavanadate is immediately precipitate out.
